text:
Course: Foundation Degree in Health Play Specialism
Course Code: FD-HPS-25/26
Level: Undergraduate Foundation Course
Duration: 2 year course
Department: Education, Health and Law
Sub-Department: Health

Course Description:
Understand and analyse general and therapeutic play and apply this knowledge and information to inform the development of care, developmental and therapeutic play plans for the individual baby, child and young person\nevaluating therapeutic play techniques to support treatments and interventions within the role of a Health Play Specialist\nBe able to appropriately conduct general and therapeutic play to support procedures, treatments, therapy, or other actions safely and effectively.\nBe able to select appropriate play resources and provide a full range of general and therapeutic play activities that reflect the particular needs of service-users

metadata.course_title: Foundation Degree in Health Play Specialism

text:
Module: Communication and Interpersonal Skills
Module Code: W_HTH4C023R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Shelley Sanderson
Credits: 20
Year: 1
Semester: 2

Learning Outcomes:
Learning outcomes
On completion of this module students will be able to:
Knowledge and Understanding:
1. Discuss a range of communication approaches, interpersonal and intrapersonal practices to support children, young people and families (K2).
Cognitive and Intellectual skills:
2. Analyse professional situations in order to select and utilise appropriate communication styles, maintaining professional boundaries when working with children, young people and families (C2).
Professional Skills:
3. Demonstrate effective communication techniques derived from evidence-based practice to ensure the best outcomes for babies, children, young people and vulnerable individuals (P2).
Key Transferable Skills:
4. Reflect on own practice in relation to communication skills and identify strengths and areas for development (T1).
5. Demonstrate effective contribution to team working (T4).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: This module will develop students’ communication and interpersonal skills in preparation for registration as a Health Play Specialist. This module aims to: · Enable students to acquire and develop a range of skills and knowledge required to communicate effectively, including both interpersonal and intrapersonal practices.

· Develop reflection on professional communication, applying theoretical knowledge to enhance team working skills and promote ethical working practices · Provide opportunities for the development of an understanding of the fundamental principles of communication and the ways in which context and content may influence approaches.

Assessment: E- Portfolio (3000 words) 100%
Module: Communication and Interpersonal Skills
Module Code: W_HTH4C023R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Shelley Sanderson
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 29
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

Assessment Brief:
Assessment Brief\nTask 1: Communication and Interpersonal Competencies CI 1 - 6 (3000 words) 100% 1, 2, 3, 4\nYour assessment will be compiled of two observations (500 words each), three reflections (450 words each) and one short report (300 words).\nThe theories delivered within the module will feature throughout your evidence, ensuring that all learning outcomes are met.\n● You will need to discuss how effective your communication skills are when working with children, young people and other professionals in\nthe workplace setting and in meeting their needs.\n● Make reference to relevant theory and the underlying principles of effective communication.\n● Discuss, evaluate and reflect how you have deployed these communication skills and techniques when supporting children and young\npeople.\n● Discuss the application of confidentiality to ethical work-based practices.

Module: Developing Professional Practice (Professional Occupational Standard)
Module Code: W_HTH4C025R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Paula Jackson
Credits: 40
Year: 1
Semester: 1 and 2

Learning Outcomes:
Learning outcomes  
On completion of this module students will be able to:  

Knowledge and Understanding:  
Discuss theoretical underpinnings and evolving principles guiding best practice when implementing play supporting sick babies, children, young people, and vulnerable individuals. (K1)
Interpret relevant safeguarding legislation, policy and procedures within your scope of practice (K3)

Cognitive and Intellectual Skills:  
Explain how innovative approaches influence ethical work practices within the healthcare sector, drawing on practice experience. (C1)

Professional Skills:  
Demonstrate competency in SoHPS Professional Occupational Standards as defined at level 4 (P1).

Key Transferable Skills:  
Demonstrate developing autonomy with reducing need for supervision (T2) 
Communicate clearly, fluently and effectively with others (T3).

Module Description:
This module will enable students to develop the professional occupational standards at Level 4, as defined by Society of Health Play Specialists (SoHPS) in the practice assessment competencies, to allow progression to Year 2 Level 5, and ultimately professional registration. The module will provide theoretical knowledge and apply this to professional practice in the workplace.

The module aims to - 
Provide students with comprehensive knowledge of the Health Play Specialist's role, equipping them with a deeper understanding of the Health Play Specialist's contributions to the healthcare setting. 
Develop a clear understanding of best practices when working with sick babies, children, young people, and vulnerable individuals.  
Provide clinical practice experiences, enabling self-assessment and reflection, where students will create personal development plans to enhance their knowledge, skills, and behaviours.

Assessment: Task 1 ePortfolio: Practice Assessment Competencies (6000 words) 100%
Module: Developing Professional Practice (Professional Occupational Standard)
Module Code: W_HTH4C025R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Paula Jackson
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 30
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

Assessment Brief:
Complete within ePortfolio evidence and sign off for progress to Year 2, Level 5 of learning - \nInitial Workplace Interview\nOrientation to the Place of Work\nAll competency evidence completed and scored\nAll competencies achieved at a pass (competency score of 2 or 3)\nThe 200 hours of clinical practice\nStudent Self-Assessment \nFormative - End of Semester 1 Review\nFinal Review - End of Year 2\nMentor Assessment\nFormative - End of Semester 1 Review\nFinal Review - End of Year 2

Module: Developmental Approaches to Play
Module Code: W_HTH4C021R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Paula Jackson
Credits: 20
Year: 1
Semester: 2

Learning Outcomes:
Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to: Knowledge and Understanding: 1. Describe and use a range of developmental theories to discuss children’s development and their relevance to play (K1). Cognitive and Intellectual Skills: 2. Discuss a range of sources which inform ethical practices when observing, assessing, planning and supporting the developmental needs of babies, children, young people and vulnerable individuals (C1). Professional Skills: 3. Explain principles of evidence-based practice and how they guide developmentally appropriate play-based interventions, evaluating play programmes to meet the holistic developmental needs of sick babies, children, young people. (P2). 4. Demonstrate an innovative and creative approach to planned interventions (P3) Key Transferable Skills: 5. Develop autonomy in delivering developmentally appropriate play-based interventions. (T2).\n6. Collaborate effectively with the multidisciplinary team to assess, plan, implement and evaluate developmentally appropriate play programmes (T4).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: This module will focus on core principles of child development and the significance of play across the life span, with specific focus on its application within healthcare context. Key theories of child development will be explored and how play serves as a vital tool for developmental growth and wellbeing. The module will develop the learners understanding of the role of the Health Play Specialist in utilising and adapting developmental play approaches to\nsupport babies, children and young people facing health challenges. This module aims to: ● Enable learners to recognise and support children’s holistic development through play. ● Develop an awareness of factors impacting on play, understanding the impact of health, illness and hospitalisation on development and play opportunities. ● Advocate play and a rights-based approach for babies, children and young people.

Assessment: Task 1 ePortfolio Practice Assessment Competencies (1500 words) 50%
Module: Developmental Approaches to Play
Module Code: W_HTH4C021R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Paula Jackson
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 24

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1, 2, 3

Assessment Brief:
[Missing Data]

Assessment: Task 2 ePortfolio Practice Assessment Competencies (1500 words) 50%

Module: Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Young People
Module Code: W_HTH4C024R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Ben Doughty
Credits: 20
Year: 1
Semester: 1

Learning Outcomes:
21 Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to:
Knowledge and Understanding:
1. Discuss best practice when safeguarding children,
whilst involving parents/carers, colleagues and other
professional agencies within a hospital setting (K3).
Cognitive and Intellectual Skills:
2. Discuss theories in relation to identifying
vulnerability to abuse and the signs and symptoms
within complex social structures (C2).
Professional Skills:
3. Discuss historic safeguarding cases and how these
have informed new ways of working that make
babies, children, young people and vulnerable
individuals safer whilst accessing hospital services
(P1).
Transferable Skills
4. Reflect upon your own professional role working
within a team in the context of safeguarding babies,
children, young people and vulnerable individuals
and supporting their families as a health play
specialist (T1).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor:
This module investigates aspects of safeguarding babies,
children, young people and vulnerable individuals, which is
fundamental to working with sick babies and children in a
healthcare setting. It explores how to work effectively in a
multidisciplinary team to support families and protect
individuals.
This module aims to:
● Enable students to gain knowledge and understanding
of safeguarding babies, children, young people and
vulnerable individuals.
● Develop best practice in supporting families within the
legislative framework in a healthcare setting.
● Allow students to reflect and learn from historic
safeguarding cases and apply this to their own practice.

metadata.module_title: Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Young People

text:
Assessment: Presentation (15 minutes) 50%
Module: Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Young People
Module Code: W_HTH4C024R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Ben Doughty
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 8
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1, 2

Assessment Brief:
Task 1: Presentation (15 minutes) 50%\nDescribe safeguarding practices within a hospital setting, focussing on children and young\npeople. Use examples to discuss how these practices can be implemented and how these\nmight impact on those involved (including families and other professionals).\nDescribe how at least two theories could be applied to and example used above. Compare and\ncontrast these theories in relation to vulnerability to abuse and the signs and symptoms within\ncomplex social structures.\nPlease ensure that your presentation is effectively supported with appropriate references\nand includes a reference list.

metadata.module_title: Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Young People

text:
Assessment: Report (1500 words) 50%.
Module: Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Young People
Module Code: W_HTH4C024R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Ben Doughty
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 15
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 3, 4

Assessment Brief:
Task 2: Report (1500 words) 50%.\nSelect a historical case which has been professionally reviews (either through and SCR or\npublic inquiry). Describe the failings of these cases and discuss how health professionals can\nlearn from them to make babies, children, young people and vulnerable individuals safer whilst\naccessing hospital services.\nFinish the report with a reflection on your own professional role working within a team in the\ncontext of safeguarding babies, children, young people and vulnerable individuals and\nsupporting their families as a health play specialist.\nPlease ensure that your report is effectively supported with appropriate references and\nincludes a reference list.

metadata.module_title: Safeguarding Children and Vulnerable Young People

text:
Module: Academic and Digital Skills
Module Code: W_HTH4C001R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Ben Doughty
Credits: 20
Year: 1
Semester: 1

Learning Outcomes:
21 Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to: Knowledge and Understanding: 1. Explain ways of developing academic and digital skills relevant to the health sector (K2). Professional Skills: 2. Discuss innovative practice in health roles, drawing on multiple sources of evidence (P3). Key Transferable Skills: 3. Reflect on personal and professional skills, focussing on communication and digital literacy (T1). 4. Communicate effectively using contemporary methods (T3).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: The module will provide students with the underpinning skills required for undergraduate study. These skills will be transferable to their professional development journey and provide a framework to support their academic progress. The aim of this module is to: · Develop academic study skills including research and referencing.\n\n· Facilitate the development of core digital skills required for study which can be transferred into practical work environments. · Provide subject specific skills to enable them to succeed in their studies.

Assessment: Task 1 - Essay (50%) – Learning Outcomes 1 & 2 (1500 words)
Module: Academic and Digital Skills
Module Code: W_HTH4C001R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Ben Doughty
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 9
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
Learning Outcomes 1 & 2

Assessment Brief:
To demonstrate your achievement of the learning outcomes for this module you will write an\nessay that includes the following:\n● You should research and discuss contemporary and innovative practice within the\nhealth and wellbeing sector. For example, how are health and wellbeing practitioners\nusing technology to engage with service users and stakeholders? How are these new\nways of working enhancing service provision?\n● With reference to working in the health and wellbeing sector, explain ways of\ndeveloping your academic and digital skills to meet current working practices. This\ncould include remote working technologies.\nEvidence of your research for this report must be included in the form of references\nand a reference list (excluded from the word count).

Assessment: Task 2 - Electronic Presentation including Q&A (50%) Learning Outcomes 3 & 4 (15 minutes)
Module: Academic and Digital Skills
Module Code: W_HTH4C001R-2025.26
Academic Year: 1
Unit Assessor: Ben Doughty
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 14
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
Learning Outcomes 3 & 4

Assessment Brief:
Create and present an electronic presentation to a small group of your peers which\ndemonstrates reflections on your own personal and professional practice.\nFocus on communication skills in the workplace, written, verbal, and the use of technology.\nYou should include communication with individuals and groups.\nEvidence of your research for this report must be included in the form of references\nand a reference list (excluded from the word count).

Module: Ethical Working Practices in Healthcare
Module Code: W_HTH5C027R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Shelley Sanderson
Credits: 20
Year: 2
Semester: 1

Learning Outcomes:
21 Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to: Knowledge and Understanding: 1. Evaluate approaches adopted to address ethical dilemmas where they have emerged in clinical practice (K2). 2. Analyse the impact of safeguarding legislation, policy and procedures and ethical perspectives on decision making within the healthcare sector (K3) Professional Skills: 3. Evaluate clinical situations in order to make informed and appropriate judgements in relation to ethical dilemmas in the healthcare sector (P1). Key Transferable Skills 4. Communicate clearly, fluently and professionally (T3).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: This module provides the opportunity to explore complex dilemmas in decision making regarding treatment and care of children, young people, vulnerable individuals and their families. This module aims to: ● Develop knowledge and understanding of principles of healthcare ethics and English Law. ● Give an understanding of current legal and ethical issues relating to the profession.\n● Examine the influence of legislation and professional bodies on current healthcare practice for babies, children, young people and vulnerable individuals.

Assessment: Task 1 Presentation (40%)
Module: Ethical Working Practices in Healthcare
Module Code: W_HTH5C027R-2025.26
Academic Year: 2
Unit Assessor: Shelley Sanderson
Submission Location: Electronic submission.
Deadline: Friday
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 2, 4

Assessment Brief:
Assessment Brief\nThe following tasks are based on a self-selected identified case study of a healthcare ethical dilemma of\na child and/or young person. The selected case study must be discussed and agreed with your module\ntutor prior to submission. Any chosen case must be in the public domain to ensure that codes of\nconfidentiality in the workplace are met and to protect individuals.\nTask 1 Presentation (15 minutes) assesses Learning Outcomes (40%)\nExamining a self-selected case study, give a 15-minute presentation that; Identifies and critically reflects\nupon ethical dilemmas where they emerge in clinical practice. Your presentation must also include the\nkey stakeholders in the case and their viewpoints. Evaluate these viewpoints in the identified case study\nand communicate clearly and effectively their position in relation to ethical approaches.\nPlease ensure that your presentation is effectively supported with appropriate references and\nincludes a reference list.

Assessment: Task 2 Report (60%)
Module: Ethical Working Practices in Healthcare
Module Code: W_HTH5C027R-2025.26
Academic Year: 2
Unit Assessor: Shelley Sanderson
Submission Location: Electronic submission.
Deadline: Friday
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1,3

Assessment Brief:
Assessment Brief\nThe following tasks are based on a self-selected identified case study of a healthcare ethical dilemma of\na child and/or young person. The selected case study must be discussed and agreed with your module\ntutor prior to submission. Any chosen case must be in the public domain to ensure that codes of\nconfidentiality in the workplace are met and to protect individuals.\nTask 2 Report (2500 words) assesses Learning Outcomes (60%)\nWrite a report on your self-selected case study that covers the following aspects in detail.\n● An application and critical evaluation of relevant key theoretical perspectives that relate to the\nethical dilemmas in the self-selected case study.\n● Identify and analyse the impact of legislation on ethical work practices that was applied in the\nself-selected case study.\n● Critically evaluate and apply decision making theory that you consider appropriate to the case.\nPlease ensure that your report is effectively supported with appropriate references and includes\na reference list.

Module: Therapeutic Play Interventions
Module Code: W_HTH5C026R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Paula Jackson
Credits: 20
Year: 2
Semester: 1

Learning Outcomes:
Learning outcome
On completion of this module students will be able to:
Knowledge and Understanding;
1. Discuss and evaluate the current context for contemporary childhood and adolescent access to therapeutic play interventions. (K1)
Cognitive Skills:
2. Critically evaluate the current theories of the role of play in child development and the implications for cognitive, social and emotional development. (C1)
Practical and Professional Skills:
3. Analyse the different therapeutic play strategies employed in the workplace that support children, young people and vulnerable individuals' engagement with play both individually and with peers. (P1)
Key Transferable Skills:
4. Communicate effectively both written and verbally. (T3)

Module Description:
Module Descriptor:
This module provides the opportunity to examine the therapeutic play needs of sick children. 
The aim of this module is to:
Develop skills and knowledge to support children, young people, vulnerable individuals and their families using therapeutic play methods
Provide understanding and knowledge of the use of therapeutic play interventions and techniques in healthcare practice
Facilitate high quality practice when using play interventions to support the development of sick children

Assessment: ePortfolio (100%) - 9 Play Plans and 3 Mentor Discussions (3900 word equiv)
Module: Therapeutic Play Interventions
Module Code: W_HTH5C026R-2025.26
Academic Year: 2
Unit Assessor: Paula Jackson
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: 16.01.2026
Submission Format: ePortfolio

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1,2,3,4

Assessment Brief:
Assessment Brief
Task: ePortfolio 100% - 9 Play Plans and 3 Mentor Discussions
Assess, plan, implement, evaluate and analyse the different therapeutic play strategies employed in the healthcare setting that support infants, children, young people and vulnerable individuals
Develop play plans which evidence your therapeutic play interventions, skills, knowledge and behaviours. Critically evaluate and link to research and developmental theory, considering the implications for cognitive, social and emotional development.
Discuss and reflect on your learning and experiences.
9 x Play Plans – 350 words each
3 x Mentor Discussions – 250 words each
Equates to 3,900 words in total
100% Assessment however use a milestone approach to submit
Milestone 1 – TP1 Play Plan, TP2 Play Plan & TP3 Play Plan @350 words each 
Milestone 2 – TP1 Play Plan x 2, TP2 Play Plan x 2 & TP3 Play Plan x 2 @350 words each
  AND
TP1, TP2 & TP3 Mentor Discussions @ 250 words each
(LO 1,2,3,4) 
(3900 word equiv)

Module: Work Based Project
Module Code: W_HTH5C028R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Shelley Sanderson
Credits: 20
Year: 2
Semester: 2

Learning Outcomes:
21 Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to: Knowledge and Understanding: 1. Evaluate different approaches to research that could provide solutions to problems in the workplace (K2). Cognitive/Intellectual Skills 2. Analyse the ethical considerations involved in undertaking research and demonstrate their application within your own study (C1) Professional Skills 3. Demonstrate innovation and creativity in the development of solutions to work-based problems (P3) Key Transferable Skills 4. Reflect on the research outcomes and recommend an appropriate course of action to enhance working practices (T1).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: This module will give the opportunity to select an area of interest relating to the role of the health play specialist to research in more detail, either in practice or theoretically. This will facilitate a deeper knowledge of the chosen area. This module aims to:\n\n● Develop knowledge and understanding of the use of investigative techniques in healthcare practice. ● Facilitate a small-scale investigation to make recommendations for improvement in practice and / or provision. ● Promote autonomy when project planning and increase confidence in the decision-making process.

Assessment: Small-scale work-based project (Including UC Ethical Approval) 4000 words (100%)
Module: Work Based Project
Module Code: W_HTH5C028R-2025.26
Academic Year: 2
Unit Assessor: Shelley Sanderson
Submission Location: [Blackboard/Classroom/etc]
Deadline: Week 29
Submission Format: [Turnitin/Physical/Face-to-Face]

Learning Outcomes:
LO 1, 2, 3, 4

Assessment Brief:
Assessment Brief
Task 1- Plan and undertake a small-scale work based project. Produce a written evaluation of
the project. (4000 words) (100%) Assess LO’s 1, 2, 3 and 4
Investigate an aspect of healthcare that relates to the role of a health play specialist that you
feel needs consideration. Research the key values and principles pertaining to this to provide
further insight, solutions and recommendations.
● Devise a plan to conduct this small-scale work based project, which will include a clear rationale for
your choice and the research methodology, timescales, consultation, ethical considerations.
● Include the potential impact of this small scale research project on the sector.
● Conduct a literature review of historical and contemporary literature relating to the selected project
● Implement your plan, and carry out your project in your workplace
● Analyse, evaluate and interpret appropriate data relating to your project, considering how this data
relates to or impacts on your chosen research focus.
● Critically reflect upon your research and make recommendations for the sector.
Elements of the Work-Based Project will also support and form content for the
competency evidence for Research and Evidence Based Practice (REB) competencies 1,
2 & 3 within the ePortfolio Practice Assessment - Critical Reflection on Practice module.

Module: Supporting Emotional Health and Wellbeing of the Sick Child
Module Code: W_HTH5C029R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Paula Jackson
Credits: 20
Year: 2
Semester: 2

Learning Outcomes:
21 Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to: Knowledge and Understanding: 1. Appraise relevant principles and theories in relation to significant life events and stress, considering the psychological and emotional impact of a healthcare journey on sick babies, children and young people (K1). 2. Examine the impact of safeguarding legislation, policy and procedures in relation to supporting mental health and wellbeing (K3) Cognitive and Intellectual Skills: 3. Evaluate the current strategies and interventions in relation to supporting the mental health and wellbeing of sick babies, children, young people and/or vulnerable individuals (C2). Professional Skills:\n4. Relate evidence-based practice, and personal and professional value systems to supporting sick children’s emotional health and wellbeing, (P2). Key Transferable Skills: 5. Demonstrate professional autonomy to engage in ethical decision making and support the emotional wellbeing of sick children (T2).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: Building on foundational knowledge of child development and the therapeutic use of play, this Level 5 module provides theoretical understanding and practical skills to proactively support the emotional health and wellbeing of sick babies, children, and young people. Learners will explore the impact of a healthcare journey on children's emotional health and wellbeing. The module will explore evidence-informed strategies and interventions to foster resilience, facilitate emotional expression, mitigate distress\nand trauma, and promote positive coping mechanisms, thus ensuring sustainability within the often challenging healthcare environment. This module aims to: ● Provide knowledge and insight of psychological impact and mental health and wellbeing in babies, children, young people and vulnerable individuals experiencing acute or chronic healthcare journeys. ● Develop evidence-based practice and interventions to address emotional distress, anxiety, grief, and trauma. ● Challenge stereotypes, discriminatory behaviours and promote inclusion.

metadata.module_title: Supporting Emotional Health and Wellbeing of the Sick Child

text:
Module: Critical Reflection on Practice (Professional occupational standard/EPA)
Module Code: W_HTH5C030R-2025.26
Module Tutor: Paula Jackson
Credits: 40
Year: 2
Semester: 1 and 2

Learning Outcomes:
21 Learning outcomes On completion of this module students will be able to: Knowledge and Understanding: 1. Critically evaluate theoretical perspectives and key principles in relation to evidence-based practice when working as a Healthcare Play Specialist (K1). Cognitive and Intellectual Skills: 2. Analyse legal and ethical working practices and the impact on professional conduct, patient outcomes and culture within the healthcare sector (C1). 3. Analyse and integrate a comprehensive range of theoretical principles and values to address the needs of children, families and fulfil the role of health play specialist (C2). Professional Skills:\n\n4. Evaluate a range of practical situations and professional practice in the workplace for personal development (P1). 5. Integrate evidence-based practice throughout all activities within the Health Play Specialist role (P2)(P2). Key Transferable Skills: 7 Critically reflect on practice to support ongoing professional and service development (T1) 6. Demonstrate professional autonomy and independence in the workplace (T2). 7. Facilitate and actively contribute to multidisciplinary team collaboration (T4).

Module Description:
Module Descriptor: This module is a direct progression and serves as a critical extension of the ‘Developing Professional Practice’ curriculum at level 4. Its primary objective is to facilitate the comprehensive development of the knowledge, skills, and professional behaviours that underpin competent practice as a registered Health Play Specialist. Learning outcomes are mapped to, and fully aligned with, the rigorous professional standards articulated by the Society of Health Play Specialists (SoHPS). This module aims to:\n\n● Enable students to critically analyse and integrate theoretical and practical knowledge of health play practice across diverse healthcare environments, ensuring alignment with current evidence-based approaches and the evolving needs of children and families. ● Develop and refine students' professional skills and behaviours to a level of independent competence, empowering them to confidently assess, plan, implement, and evaluate complex health play interventions, strictly adhering to the professional standards. ● Cultivate professional identity and commitment to reflective practice, encouraging students to critically evaluate their own professional development and demonstrate the accountability and autonomy required for registration and ongoing professional growth as a Health Play Specialist.
